results.title: A Brexit-Weary Britain Finds Itself in a New Crisis With Brexit Overtones
results.abstract: The government has blamed problems like food shortages on the virus. With the pandemic waning, the focus in the fuel crisis is shifting to Britain’s exit from the E.U.

multimedia.caption: A line for gasoline in Coventry, England, on Tuesday. The fuel crisis seemed to be easing somewhat as panic buying subsided.

results.title: German Election Leaves Merkel’s Conservatives in Disarray
results.abstract: Sunday’s defeat has revealed a gasping conservative party. But what that means for Germany’s future is not clear as traditional left-right politics are scrambled.
results.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy

results.title: Japan’s Most Popular Candidate for Prime Minister Is Far From a Shoo-In
results.abstract: Taro Kono has by far the highest poll numbers of any candidate to lead the governing Liberal Democrats. But party elders don’t think so highly of him.

results.title: ‘I Can’t Imagine a Good Future’: Young Iranians Increasingly Want Out
results.abstract: Divorce is up, fertility rates are down and many from Iran’s younger generation are postponing weddings and searching for ways to leave the country in the face of economic and political stagnation.

multimedia.caption: A store in Tehran that sells fortune poems and religious books. Many Iranians are straining under years of economic mismanagement and American sanctions.

results.title: Why Haitians in Chile Keep Heading North to the U.S.
results.abstract: Many of the Haitian migrants who recently entered Texas had taken refuge for years in Chile. Some said they faced increasing joblessness, poverty and hostility there.
results.byline: By Pascale Bonnefoy and Cristobal Olivares

results.title: North Korea Launches Short-Range Missile as Country’s Envoy Speaks at U.N.
results.abstract: The launch came just three days after the sister of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said the country would consider holding a meeting with the South and declaring an official end to the Korean War.

results.title: Scotland’s Oil Industry Is Fading as Wind Energy Beckons
results.abstract: Oil and gas production in the North Sea is not the economic juggernaut it once was. Can floating wind turbines offer an alternative?

results.title: Wole Soyinka Is Not Going Anywhere
results.abstract: The Nobel laureate, whose new novel, “Chronicles From the Land of the Happiest People on Earth,” is his first in nearly 50 years, refuses to back down when he senses that his homeland’s freedom is under threat.
des_facet: Chronicles From the Land of the Happiest People on Earth (Book)

multimedia.caption: “Unfortunately, some of us are not very wise. We know what we ought to do, when we should retire, go and hide out somewhere, live a life of ease,” Wole Soyinka said. “But we don’t take our own advice, do we?”
multimedia.copyright: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times

results.title: As Gas Stations Run Dry, Britons Cope With Disruptions to Daily Life
results.abstract: Getting to work, driving a taxi, making an ambulance run: Fuel shortages and long lines at gas stations have Britons scrambling to make trips they once took for granted.
results.byline: By Stephen Castle, Jenny Gross and Aina J. Khan

results.title: Why Britain Is Embracing Pounds and Ounces
results.abstract: Britain is planning a future that relies on greater usage of its imperial system of weights and measurements. Here’s why it’s happening now.

results.title: China’s Vow to Reduce Abortions Sparks Public Worries
results.abstract: The short mention in a sweeping health plan lacked specifics, but it set off concerns in a country with a history of intrusive reproductive policies.

multimedia.caption: An amusement park in Beijing. Over the past decade, as the government has realized the consequences of a slow-growing population, officials have exhorted women to have more children.

results.title: As Tunisia’s President Cements One-Man Rule, Opposition Grows
results.abstract: In his latest step to consolidate power, President Kais Saied set up a system under which he will essentially govern the country by decree, bypassing the Constitution.

multimedia.caption: President Kais Saied of Tunisia at the Carthage Palace, his official residence, in 2019. Mr. Saied froze Parliament, fired the prime minister and seized power on July 25.
multimedia.copyright: Khaled Nasraoui/picture alliance, via Getty Images)

results.title: Catalan Separatist Leaves Italy, Dodging Spain’s Latest Effort to Prosecute Him
results.abstract: After briefly holding Carles Puigdemont on a Spanish arrest warrant, Italian authorities released him, and he left the country on Monday.

results.title: Intimate Portraits of Mexico’s Third-Gender Muxes
results.abstract: On the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in southern Mexico, a community of the local Zapotec people has long accepted — and celebrated — gender nonconformity.
